attributes.title: Lamb Weston falls after seeing unfavorable pricing/mix in FQ2
attributes.content:
Lamb Weston Holdings (LW) fell in Friday trading after the Idaho-based company pointed to improved trends with chicken fast-food restaurants.

Sales on a constant currency basis were flat during the quarter that ended on November 23, as an 8% increase in volume was more than offset by an 8% decline in price/mix. The company said volume growth was driven by customer wins, share gains, and retention, particularly in North America and Asia. The decline in price/mix was noted to reflect the ongoing support of customers through price and trade, including the carryover impact of fiscal 2025 pricing, in a competitive global market environment.

Adjusted gross profit fell during the quarter due to unfavorable price/mix. Total manufacturing cost per pound was lower, reflecting the benefits from cost savings initiatives and improved operating efficiencies in the North America segment. Those initiatives more than offset inflationary pressures in key input categories other than raw product and higher manufacturing costs per pound in the international segment due to less favorable operating conditions and elevated production expenses.

Non-GAAP EPS of $0.69 beat the consensus estimate of $0.65 but was lower than last year's mark of $0.73.

Lamb Weston (LW) is a major supplier to McDonald's (MCD), Burger King (QSR), Wendy's (WEN), Taco Bell (YUM), Pizza Hut (YUM), and Popeye's (QSR), which gives its earnings report some weight.

"Our team is executing at a high level, and we remain on track to achieve our $100 million cost savings program target for fiscal 2026," highlighted CEO Mike Smith. On the guidance front, Lamb Weston (LW) reaffirmed its outlook for FY26 revenue of $6.35 billion to $6.45 billion (midpoint $6.40 billion) vs. $6.53 billion consensus.

Shares of Lamb Weston (LW) were down 7.3% in premarket trading to erase the gains that had built up over the last six weeks.

  • Lamb Weston: A Fry Utility Trapped In A Capacity Cycle
  • Lamb Weston: Stability Returns, But Performance Is Far From Impressive
  • Lamb Weston Q2 2026 Earnings Preview
  • SA Quant ranks top packaged food and meat stocks as Campbell's beats Q1 estimates

quickInsights.question: Why did Lamb Weston Holdings' sales remain flat despite volume growth?
quickInsights.answer: Sales were flat because an 8% volume increase was fully offset by an 8% decline in price/mix, reflecting price support for customers in a competitive global market.

quickInsights.question: How did manufacturing efficiencies and inflation affect Lamb Weston Holdings' profits?
quickInsights.answer: Improved operating efficiencies and cost-saving initiatives offset inflation in key input areas, but profits still fell due to unfavorable price/mix and higher costs internationally.

quickInsights.question: What is the significance of Lamb Weston Holdings reaffirming its FY26 revenue guidance?
quickInsights.answer: Reaffirming guidance suggests management confidence despite recent profit pressures, but expected revenue is below the consensus estimate.

attributes.originalTitle: Lamb Weston falls after seeing unfavorable pricing/mix in FQ2

attributes.bio: Clark Schultz covers the consumer sector for Seeking Alpha as a Senior Editor. He writes the weekly Catalyst Watch preview of coming market events, the weekly Stocks to Watch article, and Wall Street Breakfast Sunday article. He graduated from Washington University in St. Louis with a degree in Economics. He has over 15 years of experience contributing content to major financial websites. In addition, he created the websites MoneyRates.com and Savings-Investor.com before selling them to a San Francisco-based company. Clark lives in St. Louis, Missouri with his wife and three kids. Follow on Twitter @ClarkSchultz. E-mail tips/suggestions to Clark@SeekingAlpha.com.
